This branch is composed of two houses: the House of Representatives and the Senate. The House of Representatives has 435 members, each representing a district in one of the 50 states, while the Senate has 100 members, with two senators representing each state.

The legislative process begins with the introduction of a bill, which can be proposed by any member of Congress. The bill is then referred to a committee, which reviews and debates the bill before sending it to the full House or Senate for a vote. If the bill passes in both the House and Senate, it is sent to the President for signature. If the President signs the bill, it becomes a law. If the President vetoes the bill, it is sent back to Congress, where a two-thirds majority vote in both the House and Senate is required to override the veto and make the bill into a law.

The power to make federal laws is granted to Congress by Article I, Section 1 of the United States Constitution, which states that "All legislative Powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United States, which shall consist of a Senate and House of Representatives." This grant of power is further reinforced by the Supremacy Clause of the Constitution, which states that federal laws are the supreme law of the land and take precedence over state laws.

In conclusion, the legislative branch of the US government, specifically Congress, has the power to make federal laws. This power is granted by the Constitution and is a fundamental aspect of the system of government established by the founding fathers.

Fact 1: The English Civil War (1642-1651)

One of the most significant events that led to the decline of the monarchy in England was the English Civil War, which lasted from 1642 to 1651.
